headline: Can Writers Still ‘Make It New’?
leadPara: Pankaj Mishra and Benjamin Moser debate whether there is any true novelty left for writers to explore.
abstract: Pankaj Mishra and Benjamin Moser discuss literary modernism and whether there is any true novelty left for writers to explore.

headline: As Early Elections Near, Greek Legislators Disband
leadPara: The vote, which is due to be held Jan. 25, will pit the prime minister’s party against a left-wing group opposed to recent austerity measures.
abstract: Greek Parliament is dissolved after failing to choose president; early general elections are widely seen as referendum on austerity programs as left-wing opposition candidate Alexis Tsipras, who has vowed to demand cancellation of country's debts, emerges as front-runner.

headline: Inside a Chinese Test-Prep Factory
leadPara: Thousands of students travel to Maotanchang to spend 16 hours a day, seven days a week, studying for the biggest test of their lives.
abstract: Thousands of students from around the secluded town of Maotanchang in China's eastern Anhui province attend its high school to prepare for annual national college-entrance examination known as gaokao; Maotanchang is unique in that its sole industry is cram schools, where students study for gaokao 16 hours a day, seven days a week; gaokao has come under fire pressure it puts on students, as it is sole criterion on which college admission is based.

headline: Don’t Hack the Envelope, Please
leadPara: On the eve of the Academy Awards, the movie industry faces shrinking screens and studio databases that appear increasingly susceptible to thievery.
abstract: A O Scott and Manohla Dargis share their thoughts on Academy Award selection process.

headline: Edward Herrmann, Actor With a Noble Air, Dies at 71
leadPara: Mr. Herrmann could be formidable or friendly and was often cast in movies and on television in affluent roles as a lawyer, judge or millionaire.
abstract: Edward Herrmann, a stalwart American actor of patrician bearing known for his eloquent work in movies, television, plays, audiobooks and advertisements, dies at age 71.

headline: Anti-Putin Protest Fizzles as Police Sweep Square
leadPara: A crackdown showed that Russia’s “white ribbon” movement has withered three years after it roared to life hoping to oust Vladimir V. Putin from power.
abstract: Few remaining Russian demonstrators protesting conviction of anticorruption activist Alexsei A Navalny are removed by riot police from Moscow's Manezh Square; Russia's 'white ribbon' opposition movement, which has been working to oust Pres Vladimir Putin since 2011, continues to dwindle as members are prosecuted, flee country or give up hope.

headline: Five Surprising Economic Trends in 2014, and What They Mean for 2015
leadPara: One of the foremost challenges is finding a way to get the world’s major economies humming enough that deflation is no longer a worry.
abstract: The Upshot; forces that will shape global economy in 2015 may best be understood by examination of the biggest global market moves that took place in 2014, including epic collapse in oil prices and growing strength of the American dollar.

headline: Russia’s Lost Time
leadPara: Putin excels at tripping up his enemies, but his country is growing dangerously out of step with the rest of the world.

headline: Carmakers Take a Hint From Tablets
leadPara: By adopting tabletlike, touch-screen systems, automakers are integrating smartphones and online services with fewer complicated controls that frustrate and distract drivers.
abstract: Wheels column; automakers are beginning to use tablet computer-like systems to simplify dashboard controls for drivers, in effort to counteract driver distraction; Ford is installing new touch-screen, tabletlike system to replace its complex connected-car designs; integration of smartphones and online services into cars reflects profound transformation of vehicles.

headline: Movie Listings for Jan. 2-8
leadPara: A critical guide to movies playing in theaters, as well as a selected overview of film series.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Jan. 2-8
leadPara: A selected, critical guide to the visual arts in New York City.

headline: Vanguard of Syria’s Uprising, Now on the Run From ISIS, Weighs a Bleak Future
leadPara: Syrian fighters and activists who once gathered in southern Turkey to plan a revolution are now marooned, their hopes rapidly deflating.
abstract: Antakya Journal; Turkish city of Antakya, which is on border with Syria, experienced boom in early days of Syrian conflict when foreign fighters and activists used it as way station in their journey to join insurgents fighting government of Syrian Pres Bashar al-Assad; many of young men who joined insurgency have returned to Antakya, where they live a marooned existence, their hopes for future dashed with failure of revolution.

headline: Sri Lanka’s Violent Buddhists
leadPara: Hard-line monks are an increasingly powerful political force, and Tamils and Muslims are paying the price.

headline: ‘To Make Men Free,’ by Heather Cox Richardson
leadPara: What is the proper role of government? A history of the Republican Party traces its responses to that question.
abstract: Jonathan Rauch reviews book To Make Men Free: A History of the Republican Party by Heather Cox Richardson.

headline: Brahms From Different Batons
leadPara: Two conductors, both leading German orchestras, have released sets of Brahms’s symphonies within a year of each other. What’s the difference?
abstract: Conductors Riccardo Chailly and Christian Thielemann, who have vastly different conducting styles, have both released recordings of Brahms's four symphonies.

headline: The Olden Days, With Nymphs and Trolls
leadPara: The Royal Danish Ballet will perform the work of the 19th-century Romantic August Bournonville in a program of excerpts at the Joyce Theater.
abstract: Royal Danish Ballet will perform program of dances by August Bournonville at Joyce Theater.

headline: Gay Marriage Prompts Call for Clergy to Shun Civil Ceremonies
leadPara: A pledge taken by some pastors not to sign state marriage licenses has stirred a debate in the conservative Christian world over the church’s connection to culture and government.
abstract: Mark Oppenheimer Beliefs column; some clergy members in states where same-sex marriage is legal have taken pledge not to sign state marriage licenses.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

headline: Gasoline-Tax Increase Finds Little Support
leadPara: Advocates like Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee find it tough to penetrate Washington’s antitax mood, even as gas prices fall and federal transportation funds face huge deficits.
abstract: Advocates for gas tax increase are frustrated by lack of support even as gas prices are falling and Highway Trust Fund, which pays for upkeep of public transit systems and roadways, is facing estimated $160 billion deficit over ten years; Energy Information Administration estimate average American household will pay far less on gasoline in 2015 than in 2014, which advocates of gas tax point to as proof that now is time to increase tax.

headline: Radical Islam, Nihilist Rage
leadPara: Jihadism fills the void left by failed political ideologies.
abstract: Kenan Malik Op-Ed article argues that terrorism and brutality carried out by groups in name of Islam should inspire people to question why rage against West manifests itself in such nihilistic way and why radical Islam seems to be its main conduit; posits that roots of such fanatical violence are found in failure of political ideologies that has left inchoate rage against modernity.

headline: A Weary Greece Considers Its Options
leadPara: Voters, battered by misguided austerity policies, are looking beyond mainstream political parties.
abstract: Editorial questions wisdom of European Commission, European Central Bank and International Monetary Fund insisting on absolutist position regarding necessity of austerity measures in Greece; notes that even IMF has acknowledged that such policies have left country with unmanageable debt; warns that no matter what happens in Greek parliamentary election, it is clear voters demand change.

headline: Edward W. Brooke III, 95, Senate Pioneer, Is Dead
leadPara: A liberal Republican from Massachusetts, Mr. Brooke in 1966 became the first African-American popularly elected to the Senate.
abstract: Edward W Brooke III, who in 1966 became first African-American elected to United States Senate by popular vote, dies at age 95; he won as Republican in mostly Democratic Massachusetts.

headline: An Algerian Author Fights Back Against a Fatwa
leadPara: There are elements of the absurd about the plight of Kamel Daoud, whose debut novel reaped glowing reviews, literary honors and then, suddenly, demands for his execution.
abstract: Algerian author Kamel Daoud is fighting back after his debut novel Meursault, Counter-Investigation garnered not only acclaim, but also calls from an Salafist imam for his execution; has filed criminal complaint over death threats.

headline: Border Clash With Iraqis Kills Seven, Saudis Say
leadPara: Four assailants fired automatic weapons and detonated suicide belts in a confrontation that left them and three Saudi border guards dead.
abstract: Four heavily armed men trying to cross border from Iraq into Saudi Arabia are killed during clash with Saudi border patrol, along with three guards; incident could stoke fears of jihadist infiltrations, although it is unclear which group is responsible for attack.

keywords.name: organizations

headline: Albums From Art Hirahara and Death Grips
leadPara: Mr. Hirahara’s “Libations & Meditations” is thoughtfully assured; Death Grips teaches you to listen with your defenses up.
abstract: Nate Chinen reviews Art Hirahara album Libations & Meditations; Ben Ratliff reviews Death Grips album Fashion Week.

headline: The Problem With Meaning
leadPara: Our fuzzy modern idea of “meaning” is a poor substitute for real moral architecture.
abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column examines the concept of 'meaning,' suggesting it has come to be a catch-all phrase for spiritual yearning in contemporary culture; observes the pursuit of 'meaning' can be far too subjective and vacuous, and remains a poor substitute for the enduring moral architecture that informed the lives of great figures in the past.

headline: Miranda July: By the Book
leadPara: The director, screenwriter, actor, artist and author, most recently, of “The First Bad Man,” can’t stand Garfield. “That dumb man and his dumb, mean cat have gotten more of our attention than they deserve.”
abstract: By the Book Interview with Miranda July, whose latest book is The First Bad Man.

headline: Charlie Hebdo Editor Made Provocation His Mission
leadPara: Stéphane Charbonnier, editor of the satirical weekly who was killed in an attack on the newspaper’s offices Wednesday, was instrumental in a series of defiant campaigns.

headline: ‘Dangerous Moment’ for Europe, as Fear and Resentment Grow
leadPara: The strike against the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo seems certain to accelerate the growth of anti-Islamic sentiment in Europe.
abstract: Militant attack on French newspaper Charlie Hebdo threatens to exacerbate anti-immigrant and right-wing views already taking hold in Europe; such attitudes have been on rise, propelled in part by stagnant economy and high unemployment.

headline: A New Retrospective of Jesús Rafael Soto Debuts on Both Sides of the Atlantic
abstract: The late midcentury artist is the subject of an exhibition at Emmanuel Perrotin’s galleries in New York and Paris.

headline: Brick by Tiny Brick
leadPara: Using Legos, Adam Reed Tucker has built a model of Frank Lloyd Wright’s Taliesin West.
abstract: Q&A with professional Lego modeler Adam Reed Tucker, one of the few Lego certified builders in the world; Tucker's latest project is model of Taliesin West, Frank Lloyd Wright's winter home and school in Scottsdale, Ariz, for the Wright Foundation.

headline: Proud to Offend, Charlie Hebdo Carries Torch of Political Provocation
leadPara: The struggling satirical paper was once firebombed, but it continued to amuse and horrify, taking pride in offending one and all.
abstract: French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, where 12 people were killed in terrorist attack, had previously undergone firebombing, computer hacking and death threats in response to its inflammatory cartoons mocking Muslim extremists; paper's editor Stephane Charbonnier, who was killed in attack, refused to tone down satire, part of longstanding tradition familiar to many Europeans.

headline: Violence Grows in Yemen as Al Qaeda Tries to Fight Its Way Back
leadPara: Houthi fighters seized control of the Yemeni capital of Sana in September, promising radical political reforms, but Sunni extremists have retaliated with growing ferocity.
abstract: Yemen is reeling from some of worst violence in years as militants, particularly Sunni extremists with Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, seek to regain territory captured by Houthi fighters; many in part blame country's government for failing to assert itself and leaving country rudderless.

headline: Two Brothers Suspected in Killings Were Known to French Intelligence Services
leadPara: The slaughter raised questions about how Chérif Kouachi, so well-known to the police for so many years, and Said, his brother, managed to conceal their intentions.
abstract: Brothers Cherif and Said Kouachi, suspects in terrorist attack on newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris, had been known to French authorities for years as potential extremists, raising questions of how they managed to conceal their intentions prior to attack.

headline: The Men Behind the Cartoons at Charlie Hebdo
leadPara: According to those who knew them and followed their work, the four cartoonists who were killed Wednesday represented a radical, crude and vital strain of French culture.

headline: Sri Lankan President Concedes Defeat After Startling Upset
leadPara: Sri Lanka’s longtime president, Mahinda Rajapaksa, conceded after he unexpectedly lost his bid for re-election to a former health minister Maithripala Sirisena.
abstract: Sri Lankan Pres Mahinda Rajapaksa concedes after unanticipated loss of presidential election; former Health Min Maithripala Sirisena will take oath of office.

headline: Recounting a Bustling Office at Charlie Hebdo, Then a ‘Vision of Horror’
leadPara: As witnesses recounted the massacre at the French satirical newspaper, details emerged of a routine day turned violent.
abstract: Witnesses of the massacre at Parisian offices of satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo recall and describe horrific events of what began as typical busy day; say gunmen, identified as Said and Cherif Kouachi, killed editor Stephane Charbonnier and 11 other people in five minutes of terror.

headline: Updates on the 2nd Day of Search for Suspects in Charlie Hebdo Shooting
abstract: As the manhunt continued, France extended its highest level terror alert to Picardy, a region north of greater Paris.

headline: Sebastian Seung’s Quest to Map the Human Brain
leadPara: Using crowdsourcing and artificial intelligence, a Princeton neuroscientist is hoping to map the intricate wiring of the human brain. If he succeeds, could we live forever as data?
abstract: Gareth Cook profile of Sebastian Seung, who gave up promising career as neuroscience professor for highly speculative project that sought to map human brain; Seung was widely regarded as having made a mistake until in 2014 he published article in journal Nature demonstrating that brain map was possible through use of artifical intelligence and online game called EyeWire.

headline: Man Convicted of Environmental Terrorism Is Freed
leadPara: The man, Eric McDavid, 37, was convicted in 2007 of conspiring to bomb several targets near Sacramento, Calif., as part of a radical environmental campaign.
abstract: Eric McDavid, serving 19-year prison term in California for environmental terrorism, gains early release after Federal District Court Judge Morrison C England Jr in Sacramento accepts settlement acknowledging authorities had withheld documents during his trial; McDavis was convicted in 2007 of conspiring to bomb targets near Sacramento as part of radical environmental campaign.

headline: No Safety for Christians in the Mideast
leadPara: For decades, Christian communities in the Middle East have dwindled, and an acceleration of this trend is fundamentally rewriting the region's demography.

headline: Times Readers on the Charlie Hebdo Massacre
abstract: Many wondered why The Times had not printed the cartoons.

headline: Al Qaeda Trained Suspect in Paris Terror Attack, Official Says
leadPara: Saïd Kouachi, 34, one of the two brothers suspected of killing 12 people at a newspaper, spent “a few months” with an Al Qaeda affiliate in Yemen, a U.S. official said.
abstract: American officials say Said Kouachi, one of two brothers suspected of massacring 12 people at French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris, traveled to Yemen in 2011 for terrorist training from Al Qaeda's affiliate there before returning to France; Kouachi and younger brother Cherif have been under observation by French and United States officials for years; French and American intelligence agencies are investigating whether Al Qaeda in Yemen is behind attack.

abstract: Roberta Smith Critic's Notebook remarks on diversity of works in Metropolitan Museum of Art exhibit Reimagining Modernism: 1900-1950.

headline: Voices Join Greek Left's Call for a New Deal on Debt
abstract: One view about Greece is that a restructuring, as advocated by the leader of a left-of-center coalition, would not be as radical a step as investors fear.

headline: From Sergeant-at-Arms to Canadian Ambassador, After Ottawa Attack
leadPara: Kevin Vickers, the sergeant-at-arms of Canada’s House of Commons, rose from relative obscurity when his role in ending an attack on Parliament was revealed.
abstract: Kevin Vickers, sergeant-at-arms of Canada’s House of Commons, is named ambassador to Ireland, although he has little diplomatic experience; he became a hero in October, 2014, when he killed a gunman who had stormed Parliament.

headline: Scorch Marks and Questions Linger After N.A.A.C.P. Bombing in Colorado
leadPara: F.B.I. investigators are trying to find whoever set off a makeshift bomb outside an N.A.A.C.P. office in Colorado Springs, in what could be a bias attack or a case of domestic terrorism.
abstract: Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating makeshift bomb that was set off outside NAACP office in Colorado Springs, Colo.

abstract: Times reporters and editors are providing live updates following two hostage standoffs in France on Friday.

headline: Charlie Hebdo and the Assault on French Identity
leadPara: The attackers struck Charlie Hebdo because it is a symbol of our freedom. But we will hold firm to our values.

headline: Retrograde Beliefs
leadPara: In defense of magical thinking.
abstract: First column by Kristin Dombek suggests that criticisms of astrological thinking, like influence of planet Mercury on technology and behavior, fail to recognize utility of type of thinking that tries to connect cosmic motion to to human activity.

headline: The Cannabis Queen of Beverly Hills
leadPara: Marijuana is becoming increasingly legal. Cheryl Shuman wants to make it increasingly glamorous.
abstract: Theodore Ross profile of Cheryl Shuman, founder of Beverly Hills Cannabis Club, who has sought to capitalize on legalization of marijuana and hopes to imbue culture surrounding drug with more glamor; Shuman and other women who are willing to publicly advocate for marijuana have become power brokers in the movement, and while activists dislike her entrepreneurial drive, they cannot dismiss fact that she is one of leaders of discussion.

headline: Insider Tips: Culture in 2015
abstract: As a special thanks to Insiders, Times editors and reporters are giving the gift of great recommendations for 2015. Dan Wakin, deputy culture editor, offers the first list.

headline: ‘China 1945,’ by Richard Bernstein
leadPara: With the defeat of Japan, the United States hoped to prevent civil war in China.
abstract: Thomas J Christensen reviews book China 1945: Mao's Revolution and America's Fateful Choice by Richard Bernstein.

keywords.value: China 1945: Mao's Revolution and America's Fateful Choice (Book)

headline: Israelis Link Attacks to Their Own Struggles
leadPara: For many Israelis, any terrorism by Islamic extremists bolsters the view that their conflict with the Palestinians is part of a larger clash of civilizations.
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Minister Benjamin Netanyahu condemns attack that killed 12 people in Paris at the offices of satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo; links Paris suspects to Israel’s enemies, and likens massacre to rockets fired at Israel from the Gaza Strip.

headline: If at First You Don’t Succeed, Try Scaling Back Your Dream
leadPara: Jeremy Chess, the producer of “Soul Doctor,” hopes for success as the play moves to an Off Broadway stage.
abstract: Producer Jeremy Chess reopoens failed Broadway musical Soul Doctor in scaled-down, Off Broadway production; hopes to take show on tour, bringing music and teachings of folk-music rabbi Shlomo Carlebach to wider audience.

headline: Chicago Man Is Indicted on Charge of Trying to Aid ISIS
leadPara: Mohammed Hamzah Khan, a 19-year-old Muslim, was charged with trying to travel to Syria in October to join the terrorist army trying to overthrow governments in the Middle East.
abstract: Federal grand jury indicts Mohammed Hamzah Khan, 19-year-old Muslim from Chicago, on terrorism charges; is one of several disaffected Muslims in West who had become radical and tried to travel to Middle East to fight alongside Islamic State.

headline: Maher Hathout, a Powerful Voice for American Muslims, Dies at 79
leadPara: Dr. Hathout, who helped found the Islamic Center of Southern California, called on American Muslims to embrace their dual identity, and preached interfaith comity and understanding in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks.
abstract: Dr Maher Hathout,an Egyptian-born cardiologist who became an influential American Muslim leader, dies at age 79.

headline: French Premier Declares ‘War’ on Radical Islam as Paris Girds for Rally
leadPara: Law enforcement officials appealed to the public to help find Hayat Boumeddiene, the girlfriend of Amedy Coulibaly, who took hostages at a kosher supermarket.
abstract: French Prime Min Manuel Valls declares France is at war with radical Islam and urges citizens to attend planned rally in Paris to affirm country's secular values; authorities are still on high alert in wake of terrorist attacks and in anticipation of unity rally; security forces are still searching for Hayat Boumeddiene, who is suspected of having played role in attacks and is believed to have fled to Syria through Turkey.

headline: When Satire Cuts Both Ways
abstract: Can satirists sometimes be too provocative and outrageous? Should they hold themselves back?

headline: After Terrorist Attacks, Many French Muslims Wonder: What Now?
leadPara: France’s Muslim population — the largest in Europe — seems braced for a potential backlash, both political and personal, after the terrorist attacks.
abstract: French Muslims brace for potential backlash in wake of deadly terrorist attacks in Paris.

headline: French Police Say Suspect in Attack Evolved From Petty Criminal to Terrorist
leadPara: Amedy Coulibaly, who had a long criminal record, presented himself as a model employee and transformed, in plain sight, into a hardened jihadist.
abstract: Authorities are exploring how Amedy Coulibaly, suspect in French terrorist attacks, transformed from petty criminal into hardened jihadist as they continue to search for his widow Hayat Boumeddiene.

headline: After Elections, Greece Will Be in Race Against Time
leadPara: If the Syriza party wins the upcoming election, it will be under extreme pressure to perform the U-turn necessary to keep the eurozone creditors happy.

headline: Paris March Draws More Than 1 Million Into the Streets
abstract: New York Times reporters and editors are providing live updates from the scene of Sunday’s unity rally in Paris.

headline: Victims of the Terror Attacks in Paris
leadPara: A look at the lives of those who died in the attacks at Charlie Hebdo and elsewhere in Paris.
abstract: Brief profiles of 17 people who were killed in terrorist attacks in Paris, including those at newspaper Charlie Hebdo and kosher supermarket.

headline: Crouched Behind a Barricade, Until a Crude Stranger Barges In
leadPara: In Miranda July’s first novel, “The First Bad Man,” the arrival of an interloper upends the life of a depressed and solitary woman.
abstract: Michiko Kakutani reviews book The First Bad Man by Miranda July.

headline: Dryly Shattering Taboos
leadPara: Ivo Dimchev’s “Fest” and Keith Hennessey’s “Bear/Skin” had premieres at Abrons Arts Center on Thursday.
abstract: Brian Seibert reviews North American premiere of Ivo Dimchev theatrical dance performance piece Fest and premiere of Keith Hennessy one-man show Bear/Skin, at Abrons Art Center as part of American Realness festival.

headline: Don’t Look to States for New Ideas
leadPara: Why they are no longer laboratories of democracy.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Aaron Chatterji contends that states are no longer so-called 'laboratories of democracy,' and that decline in legislative innovation has come exactly as it is most needed; ascribes decline to increased partisanship at the state level, political impediments to the scalability of state laws and lack of funding during the cash-strapped recession.

headline: In Cold Political Terms, Far Right and French President Both Gain
leadPara: After the terrorist attack in France, President François Hollande and the far-right leader Marine Le Pen have seen a boost in popularity, but no one expects the praise to last very long.
abstract: French Pres Francois Hollande has received political boost amid his handling of terrorist attacks in Paris, garnering uncharacteristic praise for his calm demeanor and decisive action; incident has also boosted the fortunes of Marine Le Pen and his far-right National Front, which has made opposition to radical Islam a centerpiece of its platform; mood of solidarity is not expected to last long.

headline: United in Outrage
leadPara: By turning out in vast numbers, the marchers in Paris made an eloquent statement in support of the fundamental right of free expression.
abstract: Editorial supports massive demonstrations in Paris against terrorist attacks that claimed 17 lives; welcomes absence of political speechifying in favor of unified outrage and solidarity; calls on Europeans to avoid conclusion that all Muslim immigrants are threatening.

headline: Jihadism Born in a Paris Park and Fueled in the Prison Yard
leadPara: Members of the group behind last week’s deadly terror attacks became known by the name of a park in a neighborhood that has produced some of Europe’s most militant jihadists.
abstract: Buttes-Chaumont network, group of young, radical Muslim men in Paris that was once dismissed by some French authorities, has produced some of Europe's most militant jihadists; group's membership, strengthened in French penal system, included Cherif Kouachi, one of three terrorists who killed 17 people in Paris attacks; group's violent success raises fear that other homegrown groups in France may go unnoticed or be similarly dismissed.

headline: Q. and A.: Jimmy Lai on the Democracy Movement in Hong Kong
abstract: Jimmy Lai, who has come under attack for his anti-Communist views, speaks about his role in the Occupy Central protests, why he is distancing himself from his media company and the challenges that lie ahead.

headline: France Deploys Troops to Guard ‘Sensitive Sites’
leadPara: The authorities said that they would bolster security to protect potential targets of terrorism, putting in place one of the country’s biggest peacetime security operations.
abstract: French government, in show of readiness and seeking to reassure citizens, deploys thousands of troops and police officers to guard sites that are perceived as vulnerable, including Jewish schools; moves recall atmosphere directly following the Sept 11 attacks in the United States, and play into emerging debate in Europe between civil liberties and security.

headline: No Exit for Greece
leadPara: Greek rejection of austerity may mean another bailout, but that's the least of Europe's economic problems.

headline: When Jihadists Come Home
abstract: How should Western governments treat their citizens who return after training with Islamic extremists?

headline: The Child in the Basement
leadPara: In sweet and pleasant prose, Ursula Le Guin’s Omelas parable reveals the ugly moral dilemma at the heart of our social contract.
abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column examines The Ones Who Walk Away from Omelas, short story by Ursula Le Guin, as a parable of the social contract and how society can depend on the suffering and exploitation of outsiders; holds story is unsettling because it reveals the difficult ethical trade-offs that are part of Western society, and sparks the desire to struggle against bland acceptance of a morally ambiguous world.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: The Ones Who Walk Away from Omelas (Book)

headline: West Struggles to Halt Flow of Citizens to War Zones
leadPara: The attacks in France have given new urgency to American and European efforts to prevent their citizens from going to Muslim countries to fight, and possibly becoming threats back home.
abstract: Terrorist attacks in Paris create sense of urgency in the United States and Europe, as concerns grow that more citizens will join extremists to fight in Iraq and Syria and potentially commit acts of terror at home; officials are renewing and reevaluating their efforts to deal with existing militants and to prevent others from joining.

headline: Terror in Paris: Saving Freedom Remains the Task
leadPara: Readers share their thoughts on the attack on Charlie Hebdo and on a kosher supermarket in Paris.

headline: Charlie Hebdo’s Defiant Muhammad Cover Fuels Debate on Free Speech
leadPara: Six days after the attack on Charlie Hebdo, Muslim groups in France, Egypt and elsewhere said the newspaper’s new cover would exacerbate tensions.
abstract: French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo reveals its new cover depicting Prophet Muhammad and instantly restarts debate matching free speech against religious beliefs that has roiled Europe since the Paris terrorist massacre of 12 people; Muslim groups warn cartoon will increase tensions.

headline: Revisiting a Soviet Ballet That Was Banned in 1931
leadPara: The exhibition “Bolt” at the Gallery for Russian Arts and Design in London gives vivid life to a ballet and to the way it exemplified a cultural moment in postrevolutionary Soviet Russia.
abstract: Roslyn Sulcas Critic's Notebook on exhibit Bolt, at the Gallery for Russian Art and Design in London, paying tribute to little-known 1931 ballet by Fyodor Lopukhov; ballet, which provides an alternate narrative of Russian dance history, was banned by Soviet government for its subversive content.

headline: Europe Focuses on Emerging Threats From Smaller Crews of Terrorists
leadPara: European leaders have begun looking for ways, including enhanced surveillance powers, to prevent violence from militants acting virtually alone.
abstract: European leaders, in wake of Parisian terror massacre, are trying to find ways of stopping new types of terrorists comprising 'lone wolves' or small groups whose plottings are difficult to discern; smaller crews do less damage and kill less people than big attacks, but they cause great fear and propaganda that aids recruitment and financing for extremists.

headline: Exploring a New Role: Peacemaker in Afghanistan
leadPara: Beijing, with political and financial interests, overcomes a longstanding reluctance to get involved in regional conflicts.
abstract: Memo from China; China's diplomats have been talking with Afghan Taliban over past several months in attempt to mediate peace process; nation is motivated by border concerns and desire to tap Afghan mineral and oil deposits where Chinese firms have invested heavily.

headline: At the Fall 2015 London Men's Collections, Designers Had a Few Words to Put on Their Chests
abstract: A number of runway looks were emblazoned with messages that ranged from the promotional to the polemical.

headline: Charlie Hebdo’s New Cartoon
leadPara: Readers discuss the French paper’s new cartoon depicting Muhammad, and the situation of Jews in France.

headline: French Rein In Speech Backing Acts of Terror
leadPara: Recent court cases in Paris have raised accusations of a double standard on free speech with some pointing to a divide between cartoonists and statements made by Muslim supporters of the gunmen.
abstract: French law enforcement arrest about 100 people after employing law passed in November 2014 that dictates tough prison sentences to those speaking in support of terrorism; raises debate about double standard regarding free speech, which allows cartoonists to poke fun at religions, but criminalizes Muslims speaking in support of gunmen.

headline: France’s Jews Have No Choice but Israel
leadPara: If the only way for Jews to live in France today is behind guards with guns, perhaps emigrating makes sense.
abstract: Shmuel Rosner Op-Ed article laments that terrorist attack on kosher grocery store in Paris has raised question of whether Jews have future in France, which is home to world's third-largest Jewish community; observes that Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu has responded by calling for French Jews to move to Israel; expresses sorrow that only option Israel can offer to embattled Jews is that of escape.

headline: Movie Listings for Jan. 16-22
leadPara: A critical guide to movies playing in theaters, as well as a selected overview of film series.

headline: Do France’s Jews Have a Future?
leadPara: It is heartbreaking that all Netanyahu can offer is escape.

headline: Your Free Speech, and Mine
leadPara: An enlightened society should be able to take the punch of satire and ridicule, even coarse satire and savage ridicule.

headline: Francs, Fear and Folly
leadPara: Switzerland shows us how hard it is to fight the deflationary vortex that’s dragging down the world economy.
abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column asserts that inability of the Swiss to avoid deflationary trap through currency devaluation is cautionary tale for United States and other countries struggling to determine best economic policies and interest rates; holds no nation is immune to global economic influence.

headline: Milton Hebald, Whose Sculptures Are in Plain View, Dies at 97
leadPara: Though his name may not be familiar to many, Mr. Hebald’s work is — in Central Park and in other public spaces around the world.
abstract: Milton Hebald, sculptor of many well-known public artworks, dies at age 97.

headline: As Europe Moves Aggressively Against Terrorism, New Challenges Emerge
leadPara: A spate of police raids and arrested suspects showed the complexity of the challenge facing intelligence agencies and security services in confronting the expanding threat from radical jihadis.
abstract: Spate of arrests of terror suspects in Belgium, Germany and France both spotlights the difficulties European authorities face in confronting radical jihadists and their increasing willingness to act forcefully in advance to stop these potential threats.

headline: Argentina’s Lessons for Greece
leadPara: If elected, Alexis Tsipras must avoid the debt default and shortsighted populism that plagued the Argentines.

headline: Reading The Times With Naomi Klein
abstract: Naomi Klein discusses how she read Thursday’s Times.

headline: A French Town Linked to Jihad Asks Itself Why
leadPara: In the wake of attacks in Paris, the southern town of Lunel, population 25,700, is trying to fathom how it became a source of recruits for fighting in Syria.
abstract: Small French town of Lunel is example of difficulty authorities face in halting trend among young Muslims toward extremism, particularly in wake of terrorist attacks in Paris; Lunel Mayor Claude Arnaud says no more than 20 residents have gone to Syria, but town has received attention because many of those 20 have been killed; officials are looking into whether town has been infiltrated by jihadist cell, and some blame local mosque's leadership.

headline: A Grass-Roots Pitch in Greece Could Pay Off
leadPara: Greece under Alexis Tsipras would likely take a sharp turn from its direction of the past five years, when it has adhered to European insistence on austerity in return for aid.
abstract: People across Europe are closely watching Alex Tsipras, left wing-candidate who is poised to become next prime minister of Greece, for signs of whether he has truly moderated his views or done so for political purposes; his agenda, if appointed, includes many cost-cutting measures, salary and pension increases and tax cuts.

headline: From Amateur to Ruthless Jihadist in France
leadPara: Documents reveal how Chérif Kouachi became a professional jihadist virtually under the noses of the French authorities and, with his brother, Saïd, carried out the attack on Charlie Hebdo.
abstract: Thousands of legal documents detail radicalization of terrorist brothers Cherif and Said Kouachi over 12 years leading up to massacre of 12 people at French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris; Cherif Kouachi evolved from amateur jihadist to merciless killer virtually under noses of French authorities, who twice had him in their grasp.

headline: Redefining Mental Illness
leadPara: New research recognizes that diagnoses and drugs are not the only approach.
abstract: T M Luhrmann Op-Ed article highlights British Psychological Society report about symptoms of mental illness that dovetails with change to how National Institute of Mental Health is approaching mental disorders; observes that both approaches suggest that mental illnesses should be treated with social interventions, not just drugs.

headline: What We're Watching: Sunday Shows
abstract: Heightened concerns of terrorism threats in Western Europe following the attacks in Paris will dominate conversation on the Sunday shows.

headline: Phil Jackson Confidant Studies Historically Bad Teams, Like Knicks
leadPara: Charley Rosen, who has known Phil Jackson for 40 years, recently published a book about the 1972-73 Philadelphia 76ers, who went 9-73.
abstract: Author, coach and columnist Charley Rosen, who has known New York Knicks president Phil Jackson for 40 years, says Philadelphia 76ers of 1972-1973, who went 9-73--worst record in NBA history--were more talented than current Knicks team.

headline: Islamic State Frees 350 Elderly and Ailing Yazidis
leadPara: The Islamic State freed about 350 members of Iraq’s Yazidi minority on Saturday, delivering them to safety in the country’s northern Kurdish region.
abstract: Islamic State releases 350 members of Iraq's Yazidi minority, most of whom are elderly, disabled or sick.

headline: Protesters Out to Reclaim King’s Legacy, but in Era That Defies Comparison
leadPara: On the eve of Martin Luther King’s Birthday, protesters mobilized by the shooting deaths of young blacks and angry about racial inequality are evoking his work, denouncing what they say is an attempt to sanitize his message.
abstract: Protesters angry over shooting deaths of young black men are evoking work of Rev Dr Martin Luther King Jr on eve of his birthday, in hopes of sparking transformative protest movement; some say that radical nature of King's work has been sanitized, and that radical action is necessary to fight racial inequality; question remains as to whether protesters can built movement similar to King's in vastly different times.

headline: To Call This Threat by Its Name
leadPara: Islamist terrorism is a cancer on Islam, and Muslims must fight it at our side.

headline: A Hip-Hop ‘Spirit Guide’ and Online Taste Maker
leadPara: ASAP Yams, who died on Jan. 18 at 26, exerted a prescient influence over hip-hop both online and through ASAP Worldwide records.
abstract: Jon Caramanica An Appraisal column recalls influence of ASAP Yams, owner of ASAP Worldwide Records who helped drive Harlem rapper ASAP Rocky to fame; Yams, who died in January, is credited with bringing together disparate areas of hip-hop culture in service of forward-looking vision.

headline: Where Art and Timekeeping Meet
leadPara: Contemporary art and watchmaking have many things in common. It's a relationship watchmakers like to reinforce when selling luxury pieces.

headline: Expansion Microscopy Stretches Limits of Conventional Microscopes
leadPara: A new technique makes minute biological features, some just 70 nanometers wide, more visible through regular optical microscopes.
abstract: Dr Edward S Boyden study in journal Science reports that researchers have developed means of viewing miniscule biological structures at nearly molecular scale through ordinary optical microscopes; technique, called expansion microscopy, involves physically increasing size of tissue samples by infusing them with expanding polymer.

headline: In Retort to Paris, Chechens Denounce ‘Permissiveness’
leadPara: Tens of thousands of people marched on Monday through Grozny in a conservative retort to the mass demonstrations in France this month expressing solidarity with the victims of the terror attacks in Paris.

headline: French Premier Says ‘Apartheid’ Is Leaving Minorities on the Fringe
leadPara: Prime Minister Manuel Valls said that France, even while fighting terrorism, must address a deeply rooted divide that has stoked tensions in immigrant communities.
abstract: French Prime Min Manuel Valls says nation has deep gulf akin to 'apartheid' that is leaving minorities on fringe of society; comments are seen as response to Paris terrorist attacks and isolation of immigrant population.

headline: Greek Left’s New Issue: All-Inclusive Resorts
leadPara: Hoteliers and others are worried by proposals that include a possible increase in the value-added tax and a plan to curb all-inclusive resort deals.
abstract: Hoteliers and other members of Greece's tourism industry face challenges from both major parties in upcoming elections; ruling New Democracy party is proposing increase in value-added tax on hotel accommodations, while leftist Syriza coalition plans to curb all-inclusive resort packages and reopen privatization deals that are already moving forward; dangers follow record year that had given rise to optimism in industry.

headline: Which Literary Figure Is Overdue for a Biography?
leadPara: Thomas Mallon and Ayana Mathis on authors whose life stories should be told.
abstract: Thomas Mallon and Ayana Mathis believe that lives of authors Tom Wolfe and Albert Murray should be considered subjects of biographies.

headline: Who Are the Houthis of Yemen?
leadPara: The Houthis are part of a Shiite rebel group from northwestern Yemen that has been battling U.S.-allied government and Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.

headline: Faith Seidenberg, 91, Dies; Took On McSorley’s, an All-Male Haven
leadPara: Ms. Seidenberg, a civil rights lawyer, is best known for successfully suing McSorley’s Old Ale House in a case in which a judge found that sex discrimination in public accommodations is unconstitutional.
abstract: Faith Seidenberg, lawyer who sued McSorley's Old Ale House to allow women, dies at age 91.

headline: Say It Like It Is
leadPara: You can’t dance around the topic of radical Islam.
abstract: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column criticizes Obama administration for failing to acknowledge that much of violent extremism in world is directly linked to radical Islam for fear of being deemed Islamophobic; argues that efforts to combat Islamic extremism is hindered by using vague language in name of sensitivity.

headline: New Party Harnesses Discontent in Greece
leadPara: With high unemployment and a struggling economy, the political field is fractured and includes a party formed just last March that is running third in the polls.
abstract: New third political party in Greece, To Potami, could put Harry Theoharis in parliamentary seat if two leading parties do not get clear majority in general election; party presents itself as one of moderation in country with high unemployment and weak economy.

headline: At the State of the Union, a President Outgunned in Congress Is Still Combative
leadPara: By raising the plight of the middle class in his State of the Union Message, President Obama firmly inserted issues of economic fairness into the political debate.
abstract: Editorial praises Pres Obama for way he addressed income inequality and economic struggles of the poor and middle class in his State of the Union address; suggests that whoever is chosen as Democratic nominee for 2016 presidential election will have to address these issues head-on; urges Obama not to compromise with Republican majority in Congress.

headline: Paris Mayor Plans to Sue Fox Over False Reports of ‘No-Go Zones’
leadPara: Mayor Anne Hidalgo announced plans to take legal action against Fox News for inaccurate reports that areas of her city are Muslim-ruled enclaves.

headline: Stabbing on Tel Aviv Bus Breaks a Fragile Calm
leadPara: The assailant, who attacked a bus driver as well as passengers during the morning rush, was shot and wounded by security forces as he tried to escape. At least three victims had serious injuries.
abstract: Palestinian man identified as Hamza Muhammad Hassan Matrouk boards bus in Tel Aviv and stabs and wounds up to a dozen Israeli passengers; police shoot and wound Hassan as he attempts to flee scene, eventually capturing him.

headline: The Megyn Kelly Moment
leadPara: The anchor has brought Fox News a more unpredictable approach to red-meat politics. Can she draw a more unpredictable audience?
abstract: Profile of Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly, whose show The Kelly File is the channel's biggest new hit in 13 years; Kelly's popularity among wide range of viewers may point way for channel to grow its aging demographic.

headline: France Vows Forceful Measures Against Terrorism
leadPara: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France announced new security measures Wednesday in Paris, including proposals to add about 2,500 new jobs to fight terrorism and monitor potential threats.
abstract: France outlines aggressive program to prevent future terrorist attacks like that at satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo; proposal, which includes updated intelligence and surveillance operations, as well as possible renewal of country's anti-terrorist 'national indignity' law, raises questions over balance of national security with civil liberties.

headline: Boehner Invites Another Response to State of Union, From Israel’s Premier
leadPara: A day after the president’s address, Speaker John A. Boehner invited Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to address a joint meeting of Congress next month for what would effectively be a rebuttal.
abstract: House Speaker John A Boehner invites Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu to address joint session of Congress in February, constituting rebuttal to Pres Obama's State of the Union address; move stuns Obama administration, in sign Republicans plan to challenge Obama on international policy, as well as domestic affairs.

abstract: Richard Sandomir Sports Business column notes that New York Knicks have worst record in NBA and loyal fans think their devotion deserves a reward; some suggest full rebate for games when stars do not appear.

leadPara: A string of stabbings by a 23-year-old Palestinian exemplifies a new threat in Israel: spontaneous attacks by individuals.
abstract: Seemingly unremarkable life of Hamza Matrouk, Palestinian man who stabbed dozen people in Tel Aviv, highlights growing trend in Israel, in which individuals without any affiliation to organizations randomly carry out terrorist attacks using easily available weapons.

headline: What's On This Week Around the World
abstract: A dance festival in The Hague, a focus on the artist Simon Starling in Mexico City and a production of “Die Fledermaus” in Tokyo are in this week’s lineup of international art events.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Jill Leovy's 'Ghettoside'
abstract: Ms. Leovy discusses “Ghettoside,” Patton Oswalt talks about his new memoir and Anita Shapira discusses “Ben-Gurion: Father of Modern Israel.”

headline: ‘Sophia: Princess, Suffragette, Revolutionary,’ by Anita Anand
leadPara: The life of a suffragist daughter of an exiled maharajah.
abstract: Suzanne Berne reviews book Sophia: Princess, Suffragette, Revolutionary by Anita Anand.

headline: After an Anxiety-Filled Campaign, Greek Voters Consider a Turn to the Left
leadPara: Battered by years of economic trouble, Greeks may turn to the leftist Alexis Tsipras and his party when they go to the polls on Sunday.
abstract: Polls indicate that many Greeks are inclined to vote for leftist firebrand Alexis Tsipras despite his relative inexperience and warnings from European officials; support for Tsipras is blooming amid climate of fear, which has been stoked by incumbent party of Prim Min Antonis Samaras, and speaks to desperation of voters who are fed up with country's situation.

headline: The Greeks Head to the Polls, Many Saying ‘Enough’
leadPara: The only surprise in the rise of the left-wing Syriza party is that it has taken so long for an anti-austerity party to come to the fore.
abstract: Serge Schmemann Editorial Observer holds that Greece’s election, in which left-wing candidate Alexis Tsipras and his anti-austerity Syriza party is expected to win, may at last signal citizens’ rejection of austerity policies that have plunged country deeper into economic malaise; argues that whoever wins must realize there is no easy exit from Greece's problems.

headline: When Calculus of Loss Doesn’t Add Up
leadPara: What makes one atrocity more newsworthy than another? An attack in Paris that was covered heavily, and one in Nigeria that got less attention, raise the question anew.
abstract: Margaret Sullivan The Public Editor column on amount of attention The New York Times focused on terrorist attack against Charlie Hebdo in Paris and Boko Haram attack on Nigerian town of Baga that resulted in as many as 2,000 deaths.

headline: Belgium Confronts the Jihadist Danger Within
leadPara: The recent thwarting of a terrorist operation highlights the dangers posed by a well-developed underground pipeline that has made Belgium the biggest per capita contributor in Europe of fighters to Syria.
abstract: Belgian government reports that 350 Belgians traveled to Syria to join extremist groups and more than 70 of them have returned home, posing severe risk to national security.

headline: Greece Chooses Anti-Austerity Party in Major Shift
leadPara: Syriza’s victory, which positions Alexis Tsipras as prime minister, comes as Europe’s economic crisis has stirred populist anger.
abstract: Left-wing Syriza party wins decisive victory in national Greek elections, positioning Alexis Tsipras to become country's next prime minister; wide margin amounts to forceful rejection of European Union's austerity measures, which Tsipras has vowed to resist, and strongest showing yet amid populist backlash that has spread across Continent.

headline: The Mill of Muslim Radicalism in France
leadPara: French prisons have become a breeding ground for Islamist extremism partly because they mistreat the Islamic faith.

headline: Greek Leftists Adopt Patti Smith Anthem ‘People Have the Power’ as Their Own
leadPara: An American rock song has become something of an unofficial anthem for Greek populists.

headline: Ending Greece’s Nightmare
leadPara: Now that Alexis Tsipras has won, and won big, European officials would be well advised to stop lecturing him on fiscal responsibility.
abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column calls on European officials to negotiate in good faith with Alexis Tsipras, likely the next Greek prime minister, and his victorious Syriza party; maintains officials should refrain from lecturing Tsipras on fiscal responsibility, saying they lost all credibility by imposing an unrealistic and catastrophic course of austerity measures on his country.

headline: Vote Result in Greece Challenges More Than Austerity
leadPara: The leftist politician created the government with a right-wing fringe party that will charge immediately into the task of reversing wrenching austerity policies.
abstract: Victory of Alexis Tsipras and his left-wing Syriza party in Greek elections is taken as both sign of Greek electorate's antipathy toward austerity policies and rejection of status quo that has allowed fringe parties on both right and left across Europe to become ascendant; Tsipras, who allied with center-right party Independent Greeks, has received praise from far-right leaders across Europe, underscoring power and breadth of anti-austerity message.

headline: Those Radical VSPs
abstract: Syriza is more mainstream than Brussels.

headline: The Surprise Isn’t That an Extreme Party Won in Greece. It’s That It Took This Long.
leadPara: The election of an anti-austerity party has been met with remarkable calm in Europe, with most European markets up.

headline: Greece’s Agonized Cry to Europe
leadPara: European leaders must hear the unambiguous message from voters: Greeks will not continue to abide by the austerity regime.
abstract: Editorial calls on Germany and other European nations to heed message sent by Greek elections, namely that nation will no longer endure disastrous austerity measures that have been imposed on it; urges European Union to extend bailout program that is set to expire in February as a token of good faith.

headline: Rand Paul Challenges Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz on Iran
abstract: He asked his fellow senators if they were ready to send ground troops.

headline: Greek Election Reflects a Deep Divide in Europe
leadPara: Beneath the austerity debate that propelled a left-wing party to victory in Greece is a conflict of wills between Greek voters and those in Germany, Finland and the Netherlands.
abstract: Win for Alexis Tsipras and his left-wing party Syriza in Greek elections underscores central tension within European Union when different countries in bloc have conflicting desires; Greece's voters oppose austerity favored by those in Germany, Finland and the Netherlands, and reconciling these opposing views is challenging task faced by eurozone finance ministers as they meet in Brussels.

headline: Marcus Borg, Liberal Scholar on Historical Jesus, Dies at 72
leadPara: Professor Borg was among a group of scholars, known as the Jesus Seminar, who set out to discern which of Jesus’ acts and utterances could be confirmed as historically true, and which were merely myths.
abstract: Prof Marcus J Borg, liberal Christian scholar, dies at age 72.

headline: Saudi Succession Hints at Shift in Foreign Role
leadPara: Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, the new deputy crown prince, embodies Saudi Arabia’s shift to a more assertive foreign policy, analysts say.
abstract: Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, newly appointed deputy crown prince of Saudi Arabia, embodies nation's shift to a more assertive foreign policy; will continue tactics he developed as interior minister, propping up allies and quashing foreign political foes and domestic dissent; Nayef, now second in line for throne, is key aspect of generational shift in the Saudi royal family following the death of King Abdullah.

headline: Save the New Ukraine
leadPara: The pro-European reformers desperately need financial aid to survive Russia’s assault.
abstract: Op-Ed article by philosopher Bernard-Henri Levy and philanthropist George Soros calls on Western nations to provide at least $15 billion in aid to shore up Ukraine's fledgling democracy as it fights back against Russian military and financial pressure; argues aid would not only protect freedom in Ukraine, but would strike significant blow against authoritarianism of Russian Pres Vladimir Putin.

headline: Elección griega expone profunda división en Europa
leadPara: El impulso por forjar una alianza se enfrenta a electores en diferentes países que tienen demandas diferentes, incluso opuestas.

headline: On the Greek Election
leadPara: Left-wing party Syriza has promised to renegotiate Greece’s debt.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Her Detractors: Reporter's Notebook
abstract: Amy Chozick describes the challenges of fairly reporting the shift in tone of the ire that is directed at Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Two Rockets Fired From Syria Hit Israeli-Controlled Part of Golan Heights
leadPara: The rockets fell on open ground and no casualties were reported. The Israeli military responded with artillery fire on the suspected launching sites.
abstract: Israel retaliates with artillery after rockets fired from Syria hit Israeli section of Golan Heights; incident inflames tensions along border already shaken up by Syria's civil war.

headline: Greece’s New Left-Wing Cabinet Signals Willingness to Confront E.U. Over Policies
leadPara: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras’s new cabinet includes Yanis Varoufakis, an economist who has called the eurozone austerity policy “fiscal waterboarding.”
abstract: Greek Prime Min Alexis Tsipras's new cabinet includes many members of his radical-left Syriza party, and among them is economist Yanis Varoufakis.

headline: New Greek Debt Deal Will Require More Brinkmanship
abstract: The markets are relaxed that the anti-bailout Syriza government can cut a new deal with creditors. But pressure points lie ahead, Neil Unmack of Reuters Breakingviews writes.

headline: Can Greece's Anti-Austerity Government Succeed?
abstract: Can Greece's new leftist government lift the country out of its economic wreckage or, by resisting its creditors, will it only make things worse?

headline: U.S. Strengths Buoy Consumers but Hurt Corporations With Business Abroad
abstract: A growing number of big American multinational companies have begun to suffer from lower oil prices and a strong dollar.

headline: Reies Tijerina, 88, Dies; Led Chicano Property Rights Movement
leadPara: Mr. Tijerina led efforts in the 1960s to seize land for Mexicans, Indians and descendants of the original Spanish settlers of what became the American Southwest.
abstract: Reies Tijerina, evangelist who led nonviolent campaign to reclaim parts of New Mexico for Mexicans, Indians and descendants of original Spanish settlers, dies at age 88.

headline: A Fury Arrives. Hypocrisy, Too.
leadPara: An unflinching exploration of jihadists is the focus of Abderrahmane Sissako’s film “Timbuktu.”
abstract: A O Scott reviews movie Timbuktu, directed by Abderrahmane Sissako and starring Ibrahim Ahmed and Toulou Kiki.

headline: Czar Putin’s Next Moves
leadPara: Is anyone paying attention to the awful things President Vladimir Putin of Russia is doing to Ukraine, not to mention his own country?
abstract: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column argues that Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin's actions in Ukraine constitute greatest geopolitical crisis in world, one that is far more worrisome than fight against Islamic State group; warns that if Putin manages to foil Ukraine's attempt to become more democratic, all countries that neighbor Russia will be in danger; underscores necessity of West providing aid to Ukraine.

headline: A Way to Hasten Bank Reform in Greece
abstract: Before Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras gets any euro zone deal on Greece’s public debt, he could make good on his promise of a permanent mortgage moratorium, write George Hay and Neil Unmack of Reuters Breakingviews.

headline: Adoptees Sought Their Roots, and Readers Reacted
abstract: A Times Magazine cover story about adoptees from South Korea resulted in a flood of responses.

headline: An Inventive Postwar Japanese Painter Has His Moment
abstract: Four exhibitions in New York and Dallas this winter and spring will showcase the work of Kazuo Shiraga, known as the “foot painter” of the underrepresented Gutai Art Association.

headline: There’s Something Funny in This Saloon
leadPara: “The Iceman Cometh,” directed by Robert Falls and starring Nathan Lane and Brian Dennehy, prepares to come to New York.
abstract: Funnyman Nathan Lane brings completely new perspective to role of Hickey in upcoming revival of Eugene O'Neill play The Iceman Cometh, which is set to open at Brooklyn Academy of Music; show is directed by Robert Falls and will also star Brian Dennehy.

headline: Why You Should Tell Your Children How Much You Make
leadPara: Discussions about family finances can start early and fit a child’s age and ability to understand, but they shouldn’t be avoided.
abstract: Ron Lieber Your Money column recommends that parents consider having frank discussions with their children about money, starting at a very early age; holds that while such conversations may initially be awkward, they can be tailored to a child's age and personality and will provide an invaluable lesson in the long term; has written book The Opposite of Spoiled: Raising Kids Who Are Grounded, Generous, and Smart About Money.

abstract: Yemen's Houthi minority are enjoying newfound place of prominence following rebel takeover of capital Sana, transforming from fringe group to legitimate movement that is beginning to draw support from country's Sunni Muslim majority; question remains as to whether group will be able to unite country long divided by sectarian tensions.

headline: Greece Steps Back Into Line With European Union Policy on Russia Sanctions

headline: A Bloom in TV’s Asian-American Desert

headline: Eurozone Takes on Quantitative Easing, and Its Risks
leadPara: The European Central Bank’s bond buying should benefit 18.4 million people without jobs. But there is a chance it will help only a privileged few.
abstract: European Central Bank's bond buying program, scheduled to start in March, is intended to help eurozone's 18.4 million unemployed residents, but it could have unwelcome consequences; some people, industries and countries will benefit from stimulus more than others.

headline: How, and Why, Apple Overtook Microsoft
leadPara: With the latest earnings reports from Microsoft and Apple, the once-unthinkable became reality: Apple’s market capitalization hit $683 billion, more than double Microsoft’s $338 billion.
abstract: James B Stewart Common Sense column observes Apple, formerly market laggard, has far distanced Microsoft in share price since January 2014; points out Apple's market capitalization has reached $683 billion, on $18 billion profit in latest quarter and revenue of $75 billion while Microsoft's cap is less than half at $338 billion; says Apple is dependent on its iPhone's success, which has 69 percent of firm's revenue.

leadPara: A algunos inversionistas les preocupa que Apple pueda volverse prisionero de su propio éxito.

abstract: Do you always like to buy new things? Or would you rather put aside your money for the future?

headline: Greece's Political Chimera
leadPara: Syriza represents the potential for change — and the danger of rolling back reforms of the past few years.

headline: Morning Agenda: Crackdown on Car Title Loans

headline: Tech Start-Ups in India Attract Big Name Investors, and Money

headline: Far-Right Party in France Tries to Push Jean-Marie Le Pen, Provocative Founder, to the Margins

abstract: Charles Isherwood reflects on Broadway season for which Tony Awards have been nominated, noting many plays dealt with issue of income inequality; says it is change of pace from usual seasons in which plays rarely broach politically relevant issues.

abstract: Teddy Wayne Future Tense column submits that contemporary narcissistic upper middle class people, while not saddled with 'yuppie' term widely used in 1980s, are still yuppies nonetheless; holds new yuppies have more varied personas than their predecessors and are more concerned with personal financial security than flagrant consumerism.

headline: Don’t Be So Sure the Economy Will Return to Normal

headline: Boko Haram Militants Raped Hundreds of Female Captives in Nigeria
