headline: Greece Over the Brink
leadPara: Ever-harsher austerity has been a dead end, and those who demand more of it have been wrong every step of the way.
abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column observes Greece has arrived at point of no return in its debt negotiations, and argues it should vote no in referendum on latest creditor demands and prepare itself to leave common European currency; contends nation has no real future within European Union's austerity-obsessed climate, and that much of the potential damage from exit has already occurred.

headline: Red, White and Bluer
abstract: Has America become more liberal?

headline: Morning Agenda: Greek Banks Closed in Debt Crisis Fallout
abstract: Greek Banks Closed in Debt Crisis Fallout | Uncharted Waters Ahead | Panic Among Hedge Funds That Bet on Greece | Puerto Rico Says It Can’t Pay Debts

headline: A Dutch-Belgian Design Showdown
leadPara: The exhibition 'Design Derby' compares 200 years of design evolution by two 2 often rival cultures.

headline: Tunisia Attack Will Get ‘Full Spectrum’ Response, British Leader Vows
leadPara: Prime Minister David Cameron sent security officials and ministers to the resort in Sousse, Tunisia, where 18 Britons have been confirmed dead.
abstract: British Prime Min David Cameron vows 'full spectrum' response to terrorist attack that left 39 tourists, at least 18 of them British, dead at beach resort in Sousse, Tunisia; does not specify security measures to be taken at home or abroad but sends hundreds of police officers and forensic experts to help Tunisian authorities.

headline: Greece’s Troubles Attract Little Sympathy From Poorer Neighbors
leadPara: Some of the most resolute opponents of cutting the Greek government any slack in its haggling with creditors have been Europe’s most deprived nations, like Bulgaria and Baltic States.
abstract: Bulgaria, like other of the poorest European Union countries, shows little sympathy for Greece as it negotiates with creditors over repayment of bailout loan.

headline: Monetary Controls in Greece Squeeze Consumers and Businesses
leadPara: The restrictions will severely impair the functioning of the Greek economy, which is already in shambles after five years of crisis.
abstract: News Analysis; restrictions imposed by Greek government on withdrawals and foreign transactions, while necessary to keep banks afloat, will significantly hobble nation's already shaky economy; shift could lead to deep cash shortages and damage to business; precedents such as Cyprus, where capital controls have taken years to be lifted, illustrate lasting detrimental impact.

headline: Greek Referendum Plan by Alexis Tsipras Tests His Power and Conviction
leadPara: From Berlin to Brussels to Washington to Athens, the same question was asked about Greece’s debt crisis: What kind of game is Mr. Tsipras playing?
abstract: Greek Prime Min Alexis Tsipras abruptly announces national referendum on deal offered by country's creditors, angering European leaders and illustrating his unpredictability.

headline: The Next Culture War
leadPara: Social conservatives are poised to heal broken pieces of society: they should do so rather than continuing to fight battles that are already over.
abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column suggests to Christian conservatives that in wake of Supreme Court decision affirming same-sex couples' right to marriage, they abandon culture war that has alienated much of country; posits social conservatives are well-equipped to attack problems like lack of stable families in impoverished areas, and should act on those skills rather than continuing to fight battles everyone else has resolved.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

headline: Arianna Huffington’s Improbable, Insatiable Content Machine
leadPara: She did more than anyone else to invent the Internet news business. After a decade, despite setbacks, she is still setting the pace.
abstract: Ariana Huffington, who pioneered Internet news and mastered art of generating visitor traffic with Huffington Post website, is still innovating decade after beginning venture; Huffington has weathered takeover by Verizon as well as significant staff turnovers.

headline: French Prosecutor Seeks Terrorism Charges Against Suspect in Decapitation Attack
leadPara: Yassine Salhi is accused of beheading his boss and attempting to cause a major explosion last week at a chemical and gas company’s plant.
abstract: Francois Molins, chief prosecutor in Paris, will seek terrorism charges against Yassine Salhi, man accused of decapitating his boss and attempting to set off explosion at chemical and gas company; Salhi denies terrorist motivation, referring instead to altercation with victim, Herve Cornara; Molins cites cellphone photos showing victim draped in Islamist flag.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

headline: United Church of Christ Approves Divestment to Aid Palestinians
leadPara: The church, a mainline Protestant denomination with about one million members, was one of three voting this week on divestment measures over Israel’s occupation of Palestinian territories.
abstract: United Church of Christ delegates vote 508 to 124 at church's general synod in Cleveland in favor of divestment and boycott of companies that profit from Israeli occupation and control of Palestinian territories; church is one largest Protestant denominations in United States, with around million members; majority of delegates also votes to call Israeli actions against Palestinians apartheid; Israel criticizes decision.

headline: Gunman at Tunisian Beach Hotel Trained With Museum Attackers
leadPara: The man who killed 38 people last week had spent time in a militant camp in Libya, overlapping with two men who killed 22 in March, security officials said Tuesday.
abstract: Tunisian officials reveal that Seifeddine Rezgui, gunman who killed 38 foreign tourists at beachside hotel, had trained with extremist group in Libya earlier in 2015; note that Chelli's training coincided with that of two gunmen who later killed 22 people in March at the National Bardo Museum in Tunis.

headline: ISIS Allies Target Hamas and Energize Gaza Extremists
leadPara: An Islamist group calling itself Supporters of the Islamic State has conducted a bombing campaign against Hamas, whom it claims is not sufficiently extreme.
abstract: Series of bombings targeting Hamas in Gaza Strip, including four attacks in May, have been attributed to extremist Islamist groups that vow loyalty to Islamic State and are attempting to challenge Hamas's power in region; groups, known as salafi-jihadis, have been energized by ISIS victories in Iraq and Syria; latest clashes are sign of their growing power.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

headline: Obama Tries to Soften European Creditors’ Stance to Salvage a Deal
leadPara: The White House has made it a point to say that Greek stability is in the United States’ national security interest as well as in its economic interest.
abstract: Pres Obama continues to push European leaders into negotiating successful deal to keep Greece in eurozone, part of ongoing push by his administration to force leaders to relax austerity demands in interest of solution; comments come even as administration braces for economic aftershocks of potential exit.

headline: Don’t Bet on Syriza
leadPara: Calling a referendum was good for the party but it will make things worse for Greece.

headline: Greece Wanted to Reframe Europe’s Austerity Debate. It Failed.
leadPara: Alexis Tsipras was hoping that the threat of a Greek exit would get Europe to blink, but Europe just kept staring.
abstract: Greek Prime Min Alexis Tsipras, in effort to change current economic policy requiring austerity in exchange for debt relief, has effectively backed himself into a corner; it does not appear that his bold move has gained support of European nations, but has in fact driven a potentially deeper wedge.

headline: Druid Theater Company Makes Shakespeare’s Histories Its Own
leadPara: The acclaimed Irish troupe condenses “Richard II,” “Henry IV, Part 1,” “Henry IV, Part 2” and “Henry V” into a seven-hour marathon performance.
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Garry Hynes, founder and director of  acclaimed Irish troupe Druid Theater Company; group is showing  its first Shakespearean presentation, DruidShakespeare: The History Plays, Mark O’Rowe's adaptation of Henriad, at Lincoln Center Festival.

headline: First Comes Sex Talk With These Renegades of Couples Therapy
leadPara: Offering the radical notion that couples should fix issues in the bedroom before tackling other concerns like communication.
abstract: Couples therapy, often focusing on emotional relationship between partners, has been expanding over past decade to include more sex therapy; different approaches and theories explored.

headline: In Greek Debt Crisis, Mixed Messages and No Progress
leadPara: European leaders have been saying distinct — sometimes directly contradictory — things about whether there’s still a bailout deal on the table, and whether they want Greece to hold its referendum.
abstract: European finance ministers hold meeting to discuss what to do about crisis in Greece, but session, much like many that have come before, yields no breakthroughs or solutions; chaos in country seems to confirm observations that Prime Min Alexis Tsipras's government is flailing and that European Union led by Germany is allowing debate over procedures and rules to get in way of any solution.

headline: Greek Referendum on Offer That Is Off the Table Baffles Voters
leadPara: Greece’s fate rests on a hard-to-understand question about an economic program that no longer exists.
abstract: Many in Greece are baffled by Greek Prime Min Alexis Tsipras's call for a referendum five days after deadline for debt payment to the International Monetary Fund passed; Tsipras has continued to veer between bitter confrontation with his country's creditors and conciliatory outreach.

headline: Dinesh D’Souza Isn’t the Real Criminal
leadPara: The writer and filmmaker on becoming an amateur jailhouse anthropologist.
abstract: Ana Marie Cox Talk interview with Dinesh D'Souza, Indian-American conservative political commentator, who discusses being imprisoned for violating campaign finance law and how it affected his view of prison system.

headline: Looking ‘White’ In the Face
abstract: “White” is a cultural signifier that is closely linked to rationalism and colonialism — and white philosophers cannot ignore it.

headline: Tom, Jerry and ‘Valerie and Her Week of Wonders’: Cat, Mouse and Head Trip
leadPara: The Czech director Jaromil Jires’s phantasmagoric workout from 1970 is part avant-garde fairy tale, part hallucination; Gene Deitch’s cartoons for MGM also came from Czechoslovakia.
abstract: J Hoberman reviews DVD releases of Czech imports: Jaromil Jires 1970 film Valerie and Her Week of Wonders, and Tom and Jerry: The Gene Deitch Collection, series of Tom and Jerry cartoons Gene Deitch directed in 1960s.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Valerie and Her Week of Wonders (Movie)

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for July 3-9
leadPara: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

headline: Hopeful Start to Greek Debt Negotiations Quickly Soured
leadPara: Why Alexis Tsipras took the extreme step of a referendum remains puzzling. But a look at the events reveals missed chances between Greece and its creditors that led him to think a deal was impossible.
abstract: Greek Prime Min Alexis Tsipras's decision to call referendum on hard-fought debt deal increases risk that country might fall out of euro, but insiders say he was left with no other choice; Germany and International Monetary Fund reportedly hardened their positions, instead of bending as deadline neared for Greece to make payment.

headline: Republican Governors Signal Their Intent to Thwart Obama’s Climate Rules
leadPara: As President Obama prepares to complete sweeping climate regulations, at least five Republican governors say they may refuse to carry out the rules in their states.
abstract: At least five Republican governors have signaled that they may refuse to carry out sweeping new climate change regulations issued by Pres Obama; refusals would set up clash between federal government and states over issue, and could hamper Obama as he seeks international partners; group includes Govs Scott Walker of Wisconsin and Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, both presidential candidates.

headline: Review: ‘Jimmy’s Hall’ Pits the Church Against a Populist Gathering Place
leadPara: Ken Loach’s film, set in Ireland in the 1930s, centers on a man of the people who turns an abandoned community center into a place to dance and dream.
abstract: Stephen Holden reviews Ken Loach film Jimmy's Hall, written by Paul Laverty, starring Barry Ward and Jim Norton.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | June 2015
abstract: A roundup of articles about teenagers that appeared in The New York Times in June.

headline: Greece’s Sorry Reckoning
leadPara: A lot more is at stake than the only stable currency the nation has had in a history punctuated by bankruptcies.
abstract: Op-Ed article by journalist Nikos Konstandaras laments that Greece's referendum on European bailout proposal presents fraught choice between two hard options; warns 'no' vote will deepen rifts that have opened both within Greece and between Greece and Europe during bailout drama; urges Greek voters to preserve unity and chance to become viable part of European Union.

headline: Partnership’s Opening Number: A Day of Jazz
leadPara: With star power and music “for everybody,” the Caramoor Center in Katonah, N.Y., hopes for bigger crowds.
abstract: Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah will present full day of jazz programming on July 18; event is opening of what will be three-year collaboration between the center and Jazz at Lincoln Center's managing and artistic director Wynton Marsalis (Metropolitan/Westchester).

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts

headline: The Appeal of Christian Piety
leadPara: Why some evangelical Christian women find church sex manuals empowering.
abstract: T M Lurhmann Op-Ed article recommends Amy DeRogatis book Saving Sex: Sexuality and Salvation in American Evangelicalism for way it offers insight into increasingly popular evangelical sex manuals for women; reflects on appeal of piety with respect to sex, and holds it may be contributing to growth of evangelical churches while other forms of Christianity experience declines.

headline: The Activist Roberts Court, 10 Years In
leadPara: John Roberts has presided over a court that has been far too willing to undermine precedent and give the powerful a helping hand.
abstract: Editorial looks back on ten years of Supreme Court under tenure of Chief Justice John Roberts Jr; cautions against viewing court as shifting leftward due to scattering of high-profile rulings, like those on same-sex marriage and Affordable Care Act; notes Roberts court has been one of the most business-friendly courts in decades, and it has shown willingness to undermine precedent in favor of the powerful.

headline: Studio Museum in Harlem Unveils Design for Expansion
leadPara: The museum, which fosters and displays the work of artists of African descent, will construct a new $122 million home designed by the British architect David Adjaye at the site of its current location.
abstract: Studio Museum in Harlem plans $122 million project to construct new home on its current West 125th Street location after realizing renovations would not address demand for more exhibition and educational programming space needed; design by architect David Adjaye meshes with brownstone neighborhood and museum's ambitions to become mainstream.

headline: Ending Greece’s Bleeding
leadPara: If Greece can’t live with the euro, it will be because the currency offers no respite for countries in trouble.
abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column praises Greek voters for rejecting demands of European creditors, outcome which will benefit not only Greece but European Union as well; suggests Greek exit from euro could be best of bad options.

headline: With Greek ‘No’ Vote, Tsipras Wins a Victory That Could Carry a Steep Price
leadPara: The Greek prime minister is likely to find it harder to strike a new financing deal quickly with European creditors.
abstract: News Analysis; Greek population's rejection of European austerity policies has boosted short term popularity of Prime Min Alexis Tsipras but may harm him in long run if failed referendum results in country falling deeper into bankruptcy.

headline: Craft Atlantic Puts Modesty on Display, With Surprises
leadPara: The store makes the fashion choices for guys, and it all works out well.
abstract: Jon Caramanica reviews Craft Atlantic, men's clothing store in Manhattan that offers basic, functional pieces that will not go out style.

headline: Greek ‘No’ May Have Its Roots in Heroic Myths and Real Resistance
leadPara: Experts and analysts say the vote sprang from a deep cultural and historical strain of defiance in apparently hopeless situations, honed over centuries.
abstract: Analysts and experts contend Greeks' bold rejection of European loan bailout deal in public referendum is rooted in deep cultural and historical vein of defiance under seemingly hopeless circumstances; focus of glorious resistance in Greek psyche is seen by many as attribute honed over centuries under oppressive Ottoman rule and encouraged by telling of heroic tales for many generations.

headline: Burt Shavitz, Scruffy Face of Burt’s Bees, Dies at 80
leadPara: After Mr. Shavitz sold his share in the company, he returned to his hermit’s existence in a 400-square-foot converted turkey coop in Parkman, Me.
abstract: Burt Shavitz, beekeeper and businessman who founded Burt's Bees natural personal care products company, dies at age 80.

headline: The Good Jobs Strategy
leadPara: Can companies offer both low prices and good jobs? Yes, a management professor finds.
abstract: Joe Nocera Op-Ed column praises ideas put forward by Prof Zeynep Ton about how companies can be competitive while offering good jobs to their employees, detailed in book The Good Jobs Strategy; suggests that Ton's research is especially trenchant at time when there is heightened worry about availability and number of good middle-class jobs.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: The Good Jobs Strategy: How the Smartest Companies Invest in Employees to Lower Costs and Boost Profits (Book)

headline: Is the Death Penalty Unconstitutional?
leadPara: Don’t listen to Justice Scalia. But don’t listen to Justice Breyer, either.

headline: ‘KL: A History of the Nazi Concentration Camps,’ by Nikolaus Wachsmann
leadPara: A historian depicts the concentration camps where many of the Holocaust’s millions died.
abstract: Roger Cohen reviews book KL: A History of the Nazi Concentration Camps by Nikolaus Wachsmann.

headline: It’s Time for Greece to Leave the Euro
leadPara: The euro zone is only hurting itself by trying to keep Greece as a member.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Jochen Bittner submits European Union has more to lose by scrambling to keep Greece in eurozone than by allowing country to quietly slip out of it; argues that by voting against terms of bailout deal Greece has broken contract that keeps euro zone together and asserts that accommodating Greece sets dangerous precedent.

headline: California’s Drought Changes Habits in the Kitchen
leadPara: In the fourth year of drought, recipes and realities are changing in kitchens and restaurants.
abstract: Restaurant chefs and home cooks in California are adjusting to water shortages imposed by state's drought by adjusting recipes and cooking methods to use less water; recipe for pressure cooker beef pho given.

headline: Milton Friedman, Irving Fisher, and Greece
abstract: Tales of a disaster foretold, many decades ago.

headline: Can Bernie Sanders Beat Hillary Clinton? Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: The reporter Patrick Healy provides insight from the Bernie Sanders campaign.

headline: ‘The Unraveling,’ by Emma Sky
leadPara: In this memoir, a British Arabist who had opposed the invasion of Iraq recounts her time advising American forces after the fall of Saddam Hussein.
abstract: Christopher Dickey reviews book The Unraveling: High Hopes and Missed Opportunities in Iraq by Emma Sky.

keywords.value: The Unraveling: High Hopes and Missed Opportunities in Iraq (Book)

headline: The Comic Book Artist Fiona Staples Gives Archie a Makeover
leadPara: The comic book artist, who received critical acclaim for her work on Saga, was asked to make Archie “someone the girls would fight over.”
abstract: Snapshot interview with comic book artist Fiona Staples, who has redrawn characters from Archie Comics in reboot of classic teen comic series.

headline: Lindsey Graham Says Republicans Are ‘in a Hole’ With Hispanics
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham disputed Donald J. Trump’s assertion that Mexican immigrants who cross into the United States are criminals, adding that he did not need a lecture from the billionaire on border security.

headline: Review: Looking Inward in Poetry Books From Ron Padgett and Nick Flynn
leadPara: Mr. Padgett writes with a sense of wonderment in “Alone and Not Alone,” while Mr. Flynn’s latest set of poems, “My Feelings,” can take an unvarnished stance.
abstract: Jeff Gordinier reviews poetry books Alone and Not Alone by Ron Padgett and My Feelings: Poems by Nick Flynn.

headline: Setting a Deadline for Greece Proves Much Easier Than Sealing a Fate
leadPara: European leaders and Greece have both sidestepped responsibility for the end game in the Greek debt crisis.
abstract: Both Greece and European Union leaders have been sidestepping responsibility for final decision as to whether Greece will stay in the euro system.

headline: Minnesota’s Somali-Americans Urge New Treatment for Would-Be Terrorists
leadPara: Some people in the state want to allow those recruited by ISIS or others like it be allowed to go back into their communities to rehabilitate them — rather than to jail.
abstract: Minneapolis and other cities with large Somali immigrant populations are grappling with issue of how to keep young men from being recruited by militant Islamist groups; issue has received intensified focus following arrest of Hamza Ahmed, Zacharia Abdurahman and Hanad Musse on charges of conspiring to travel to Syria to fight for Islamic State; Somali community leaders are seeking pretrial release of men, arguing engagement with communities and families is best means of deradicalization.

headline: The South’s Heritage Is So Much More Than a Flag
leadPara: An open letter from a musical chronicler of the Southern experience.

headline: Germany’s Failure of Vision
leadPara: The European project rejects the consolidation of power in one country’s hands. Does Angela Merkel understand that?
abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Bruce Ackerman criticizes Germany and Chancellor Angela Merkel for failing to rise to challenge of Greek crisis, first test of German leadership since end of World War II; suggests Merkel failed to understand strategic importance of Greece and treated crisis as merely economic one; urges Merkel to encourage International Monetary Fund to mediate dispute as it is the singular institution that both sides find credible.

headline: Another Flag Spurs Controversy, This Time in Spain
leadPara: A Basque flag flying for the first time at Pamplona’s city hall during this week’s running of the bulls has raised political tensions.
abstract: Appearance of Basque flag at running of bulls in Pamplona, Spain, raises tensions over renewed momentum of separatist movement.

headline: Greek Plan Accepts Austerity to Get Debt Relief
leadPara: After grim predictions of collapse in Greece, a scramble was underway to work out the details of a new plan to bring the country back from the brink.
abstract: Greek Prime Min Alexis Tsipras presents plan of austerity measures, including pension cuts, to gain new bailout package from European creditors; asks for three-year loan of 53.5 billion euros, or $59 billion and commitment to help Greece restructure its massive debt; it is unclear whether latest strategy reflects political determination to negotiate deal that keeps Greece in eurozone.

headline: Vince Staples and J. Cole, Outsiders in the Middle of Hip-Hop
leadPara: Musicians who buck the traditional hip-hop narrative of triumph and conceitedness often find themselves out of the circle of power, even with big sales.
abstract: Jon Caramanica reflects that socially provocative rappers like J Cole and Vince Staples who do not eschew to mainstream hip-hop narratives are likely to be shut out of its insider circle even if they sell lots of records.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for July 10-16
leadPara: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

headline: Review: ‘Tangerine,’ a Madcap Buddy Picture About Transgender Prostitutes
leadPara: Sean Baker’s fast, funny comedy, shot on iPhones, doesn’t dive deep into transgender identity but shows that femininity is a mask that can be slipped on and off.
abstract: Manohla Dargis reviews movie Tangerine, directed by Sean Baker and starring Kitana Kiki Rodriguez and Mya Taylor.

headline: Popularidad de banderas separatistas genera controversia en España
leadPara: La bandera roja, verde y blanca del País Vasco estuvo presente en las calles de Pamplona durante los encierros de San Fermín.

headline: Greece and Creditors Move Toward Deal, and Investor Optimism Surges
leadPara: Markets responded after the government agreed to meet most of the terms demanded by its creditors and requested a bailout as a starting point for talks.

headline: Are the Lessons of Srebrenica Being Forgotten?
leadPara: Twenty years later, Bosnia is once again coming apart.
abstract: Op-Ed article by scholar and policy expert Edward P Joseph contends 20th anniversary of Sbrenica massacre offers chance to refocus on unsettled injustices of tragedy; warns peace achieved after Bosnian war is fraying with rise of radical Islam and Russian influence, and those who deny event persist; calls upon Serbs of good faith and international community to reject revisionism and seek justice.

leadPara: An account of the bitter events of 1947 that resulted in the creation of Pakistan.
abstract: Aatish Taseer reviews book Midnight's Furies: The Deadly Legacy of India's Partition by Nisid Hajari.

leadPara: A journalist gives her account of the Egyptian uprising in 2011 and its aftermath.
abstract: Robyn Creswell reviews book Circling the Square: Stories From the Egyptian Revolution by Wendell Steavenson.

headline: Review: Harper Lee’s ‘Go Set a Watchman’ Gives Atticus Finch a Dark Side
leadPara: In Ms. Lee’s long-awaited novel, Scout Finch, or Jean Louise as she is now known, finds some disturbing truths about her father.
abstract: Michiko Kakutani reviews book Go Set a Watchman by Harper Lee; novel is essentially an earlier version of Lee's 1960 classic To Kill a Mockingbird.

headline: Belgian Liberal Basks in Viral Fame for Scolding Greek Prime Minister
leadPara: While the Greek debt crisis remains unresolved, at least one European politician clearly seems to be enjoying himself.

headline: France: Extremist Leader Gets 9 Years for Terrorism
leadPara: The chief of a dismantled radical network in France was sentenced Friday to nine years in prison for recruiting for jihad and plotting attacks against Jewish sites.
abstract: French court sentences Mohamed Achamlane to nine years in prison for his work in heading up dismantled radical Islamic Forsane Alizza group, which had plotted attacks on kosher markets and other Jewish business in Paris; Achamlane was also accused of abducting and torturing Jewish judge in Lyon; other members of group are sentenced to up to six years in prison.

headline: Addicted to Your Phone? There’s Help for That
leadPara: There’s new technology to save us from technology.
abstract: News Analysis; several companies see lucrative market in providing ways for smartphone users to cut back on how dependent they are on their phones.

headline: The Bernie Sanders Moment
leadPara: The unlikely presidential bid from the Vermont senator represents a culmination of major thinking on the left in the past half-century.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Todd Gitlin examines political history of Sen Bernie Sanders in order to offer perspective on why his presidential candidacy is attracting progressives; remarks on how Sanders campaign harkens to 1960s era and predicts influence of his supporters will be major factor in 2016 campaign.

headline: The New Child Abuse Panic
leadPara: Is it a crime to disagree with your kid’s doctor?
abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Maxine Eichner examines rise in doctors accusing parents of medical child abuse for seeking unnecessary or excessive medical treatment for their children; notes that accusations have sometimes led child welfare officials to back doctors and threaten parents with loss of custody; calls for end to medical abuse panic.

headline: Memories of Waco Siege Continue to Fuel Far-Right Groups
leadPara: As the Army prepares to start training exercises in the Southwest this week, the 1993 attack on the Branch Davidian compound looms large for antigovernment factions.

headline: Charles Winick, Author Who Challenged Views on Drugs and Gender, Dies at 92
leadPara: Mr. Winick, a professor of anthropology and sociology, was known for his research into the blurring of lines between the sexes and for his controversial views on drug addiction.
abstract: Charles Winick, professor of anthropology and sociology whose works challenged prevailing views on gender and drugs, dies at age 92.

headline: Better Contraception for Young Women
leadPara: Giving young women free access to long-term birth control nearly halved teenage pregnancy and abortion rates in Colorado. Other states should follow.
abstract: Editorial heralds contraception program in Colorado that reduced rate of teenage pregnancy by 40 percent from 2009 to 2013, largely through use of long-acting IUD contraceptives; observes that strategy, while relying on private rather than state funding, had enormous public returns in form of savings on prenatal care, deliveries and post-pregnancy care for poor mothers and their children.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

headline: Greek Merchants Fear a Way of Life Is Disappearing
leadPara: New measures, like allowing businesses to stay open on Sundays and deregulating milk and bread, may move people further from the culture they know.
abstract: Small business owners in Greece fear deal on country's debt crisis will mean end to their traditional way of life; measures in austerity package could hurt culture of small neighborhood shops in favor of corporate interests.

headline: The Bicycle and the Ride to Modern America
leadPara: Tires and tubing, mass production and women’s suffrage, highways and gas stations all were influenced by the machine featured in a new Smithsonian exhibit.
abstract: History of the bicycle in America is focus of exhibit at Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History, part of larger initiative about everyday objects called Object Pride; exhibit explores national bicycle craze at end of 19th century and examines deep and long-lasting impact of bicycle on America's industrial, cultural and even moral landscape.

headline: ‘Barbarian Days: A Surfing Life,’ by William Finnegan
leadPara: William Finnegan revisits his golden age of surfing and the classic search for the perfect wave.
abstract: Thad Ziolkowski reviews book Barbarian Days: A Surfing Life by William Finnegan.

headline: The Eurozone’s Damaging Deal for Greece
leadPara: The agreement doesn’t resolve the country’s debt crisis or its moribund economy.
abstract: Editorial laments that Greek Prime Min Alexis Tsipras caved to creditors' toughest demands; criticizes way Tsipras has navigated negotiations, including last-minute decision to hold referendum and subsequent capitulation, which went against will of Greek people; warns that Germany and other eurozone countries have done little to definitely solve crisis and that deal Greek government will probably accept will only make crisis worse.

headline: D’Army Bailey, 73, Activist Who Founded Museum Where Dr. King Was Shot, Dies
leadPara: Mr. Bailey campaigned to transform the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, site of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s assassination, into a civil rights museum.
abstract: D'Army Bailey, civil rights crusader responsible for turning motel where Rev Dr Martin Luther King Jr was assassinated into civil rights museum after long campaign, dies at age 73.

headline: Sympathy for Greeks Inspires Outraged Commentary Tagged #ThisIsACoup
leadPara: The strict terms of the debt deal imposed on Greece prompted a wave of criticism on social networks.

headline: The New Old Liberalism
leadPara: Hillary Clinton’s speech was economically naive but politically masterful.
abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column praises first major economic address delivered by Hillary Rodham Clinton in her bid for Democratic Party's presidential nomination, noting she adopted moderate tone and avoided drift toward far left that is becoming popular in party; posits that speech sounded as if Clinton has been listening to voters' very real concerns; expresses skepticism about Clinton's own faith in government's ability to manage economy, but suggests that she has passed first test of her campaign.

headline: Tsipras Is Seen as Retaining Greeks’ Approval While Selling Tough Bailout Deal
leadPara: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras seems to have helped his standing by calling for more of the required sacrifices to fall heavily on the country’s oligarchs.
abstract: Greek Prime Min Alexis Tsipras has maintained surprising level of domestic political support as he brings home bailout deal that backtracks on several of his campaign promises; many perceive Tispras as having gotten best deal possible, and believe that he will maintain his populist values as he distributes deal's burdens.

headline: When a Fictional Hero Falls
abstract: How will "To Kill a Mockingbird" be taught in U.S. schools given the revelations about Atticus Finch and his racism?

headline: Syriza Discusses Bailout Debate
leadPara: Comments by members of Syriza on Wednesday morning indicated a split opinion within the party, as they arrived at the Greek parliament to debate a bailout.

abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column maintains that establishment presidential candidates are struggling to make headway in nomination races of both parties because it is time of economic anxiety and political alienation; notes that Donald Trump is ideally suited to times, even if he will not be president.

headline: The Long History of Political Idiocy

headline: Republicans Are Trying to Turn Uber Into a Partisan Issue

headline: Can a Virtuous Character Be Interesting?

headline: Israel Detains Meir Kahane’s Grandson, a Scion of Jewish Militancy
